the giant despotism, and discovers that MI Canning

The Tennessee legislature has passed set Of re-
Solutions with .san argument" with but two dis


enug votes, declaring that the constitution OF the
u States should be amended as toglve the election
nf President .sdrectly and conclusvely" to the peo-
pie. This is not objectionable F; but they also de


clare, that the measures of til, present admins
trann Of the General Government are injurious to
the interests and dangerous to the liberties Of the
cOGnirY'-.s that the surest remedy tor these evils
now in the power Of the people. is the election Of
.4nareU Jackson to the chief maglstracy OF the
Union" This is the substance of the resou-
tuns but . the argument" which occupies nearly
two columns Of closely printed matter and which
was also adopted with the resolutions by legisla-
tive body Of one of the members of this union, IS
one Of the most singular productions which the pre-


sent controversy has given birth to, altogether un-
paralleled III the history of politics. Io give our
readers an idea of it few sentences will SUFFICE
The 9 arguments" appears to be an explanatory ap
pendix to the resolutions, which form text for IT,

corruption in the last presidential election 70
prove whchit says, . Mr. Adams desired the ONCE
OF President-he went into the combination whont
IT. and came out with it, MIR. Clay desired that of
Secretary of State-he went into the combination
without it, and came out with it. This 1t mus, be
confessed. is a summary and novel way OF arguing
polat The sages of Tennessee might as well nave
said, that the fact that Mr.. Adams was elected
proved that he owed his election to corrupt means
They enter into long argument OH the propret,
OF admitting circumstantia testimony IN the case


but do nut tell US what the circumstances are tina


prove the existence of combination" to etiec
the election of Mr.. Adams, other than the assume

each other. Falling therefore to prove the fact tha


a cnnbinaton" was formed. any inference d.


duced FROM unnamed - circumstances relative

than ridiculous. They create or imagine premise

From, the Baltimore Patriot.
JACKSONlSM IN TENNESSEE.

Apreeabiy to notice. meeting of the friends OF
the Administration was held at Brensvile in Prince
William Count,, Virginia. on the first Monday OF
the present month, at which the Hon. WIN A. y:
as Socrrt.rv We learn that the meeting was tar
more numerous than the most sangune friend Of civil
eU, government % had anticipated,-an opinion having
PREVAILED. that the County was almost unanimous in
favor of ..Conquering Hero" Of the ffty gentle.
mem present. between thirty and forty were free
holders rs Of the first responsibility, among whom we
recognize some of the most distinguished citizens Of
the State. Tn, ~,
ton. E.ors. were chosen Delegates to the proposed
convention at Richmond. A corresponding commits
tee consisting Of eleven members was appointed,
and an approproprate address and resolutions were
adopted.
From the alexandria Gazette.

We continue our summary notices OF the county
meetings in Virginia They disclose more and
more the great weight Of character which is array
,nu itself in that State against the military candle
dale for The Presidency. 1t is cheering and ausp'
cious to find SO many ofthe leading men Of Virginia,
men whose intelligence and virtue would have made
them leading citizens in the Pnrest ages OF the ah-
cient Rcpublics--lt is cheering 10 see SO grea,
n,,r;oic sentiments avowed by them, and no long
time ago supported, by those who now are violent'
| ly opposed 10 them.
VIRGINIA..

A jackson paper, referring to the late election for
a Representative in Congress, in which Mr. Stan
berry, jackson man, elected, in consequence
of there being two Administration candidates. ex-
claims: "Hurrah for Old Hickory; one Jackson man
outran two Administration men!' This is like the
rest Of the jackson logic Nat Journal
GEORGE HAFFNER."

1t appears from the speech Of Mr.. Garrett in the
Tennessee Legislature, that the editors OF newspa-
pers throughout the United States, who do not sup
port General jackson for the Presidency, are called
in that body "RAscALLY PRINTERS" we do not
wonder at this evidence of want Of respect for the
liberty of the Press and those who conduct 1t,
among body of men where the idea was entertain.
ed of furnishing editor for publishing one OF their
own resolutions !!

Too cheap by half The following very modest
and patriotic offer was made in Ohio, at the late
election, by one Of the genuine disciples OF Ol0
Hickory:


II will support the cause of Gen. Jackson in th'
Legislature at their next session, 1t the people o
this county thinks me worthy, for sirty too cent
and half per dug. ;,

full articles.headline: From the alexandria Gazette.
full articles.article:
Apreeabiy to notice. meeting of the friends OF
the Administration was held at Brensvile in Prince
William Count,, Virginia. on the first Monday OF
the present month, at which the Hon. WIN A. y:
as Socrrt.rv We learn that the meeting was tar
more numerous than the most sangune friend Of civil
eU, government % had anticipated,-an opinion having
PREVAILED. that the County was almost unanimous in
favor of ..Conquering Hero" Of the ffty gentle.
mem present. between thirty and forty were free
holders rs Of the first responsibility, among whom we
recognize some of the most distinguished citizens Of
the State. Tn, ~,
ton. E.ors. were chosen Delegates to the proposed
convention at Richmond. A corresponding commits
tee consisting Of eleven members was appointed,
and an approproprate address and resolutions were
adopted.

full articles.headline:
VIRGINIA..

From. the National Intelligencsr, Mop. 81.
full articles.article:
We continue our summary notices OF the county
meetings in Virginia They disclose more and
more the great weight Of character which is array
,nu itself in that State against the military candle
dale for The Presidency. 1t is cheering and ausp'
cious to find SO many ofthe leading men Of Virginia,
men whose intelligence and virtue would have made
them leading citizens in the Pnrest ages OF the ah-
cient Rcpublics--lt is cheering 10 see SO grea,
n,,r;oic sentiments avowed by them, and no long
time ago supported, by those who now are violent'
| ly opposed 10 them.

the sitting of the Senate without the Senate's sane

House of Representatives well as the Senate
could interpose their vote by Withholding the ap-

This most ridiculous and untounded charge is based


upon an expression of the President in his first mes

the invitation given by the South American Repub
lies to this government, to Cause itself to be repre-

commissioned" Now what Can the most iastidious
i even the members of the Tennessee legislature
i make out of this Nothing, absolutely nothing. Th'
President merely meant to convey the idea, that, 81

was concerned, the invitation was accepted, and s.
far as it was the province Of the Executive, minis
q ters would be commissioned. To prove that thu

with tha hPcP


are known to Hll and this course has been pursue

ue Presidents duty to commission envoys whom

ment says, &C our interests abroad are now Uiolt

,ce the sentence quoted above in the true spirl

alton Are we to understand fo'n 'n's rant, Una, '"e

large, CIR putt ng up ah.i transmitting them safely

eye, without attracting any other than ordinary no.


tice, it is all at discovered, that he is the great


est man in the Union, the most learned, the most


VICE. the most patriotic, of any living being the


greatest statesmen the most vrtuous, the most hon.


est and the most able naan, n the Union, anc that on

! Immediately upon the passage Of the resolutions
and argument, and to put the sentiments Of the leg


slature to the test. to how Tar they would go,
and tit commentary on the resolutions anu "ar-
gument," Mr.. Rogers introduced the resolutlon re-
quiring the members Of Congress from Tennessee
to prefer charges against the President and have
him impeached and dismissed from the Presidency.


When this resolution was called up MIR. Rogers was


ndsposed, and of course unable to give IT the pro
per support and explanaton.-Ihe members were
evidently taken by surprize, for though the resou-
ton nothing but what was right and proper, II
the sentiments Of the former resolutions aud "argu-


ment'' were we'll founded, they not prepared
to enter upon measures that would put them to the


test that would compel them to establish their char


yes by proof. ''lf reasons were as plenty as back


berries they would give no man reason upon com.


pulsion.'--The members could sit behind their desks


and write charges as their imagination invented
them, and the legislature could resolve That they
were true; but it was asking 800 much to require
them to prove their truh-The resolution was, there


fore rejected, having but three votes IN its favor


In all our .perience have never seen any thing


equal to these transactions from the Legislature OF


state. Truth. candor, patriotism, decorum, and


even legislative dignity. are made to bend to one


common purpose, and that the elevation to office OF


4 solitary ndvidual-the election to the Presidency


Of Andrew jackson. Truly the classic motto may
- fen of
inscribed in letters of iron over the door OF the
Tennessee Legislature.

full articles.headline: GEORGE HAFFNER."
full articles.article:
A jackson paper, referring to the late election for
a Representative in Congress, in which Mr. Stan
berry, jackson man, elected, in consequence
of there being two Administration candidates. ex-
claims: "Hurrah for Old Hickory; one Jackson man
outran two Administration men!' This is like the
rest Of the jackson logic Nat Journal

1t appears from the speech Of Mr.. Garrett in the
Tennessee Legislature, that the editors OF newspa-
pers throughout the United States, who do not sup
port General jackson for the Presidency, are called
in that body "RAscALLY PRINTERS" we do not
wonder at this evidence of want Of respect for the
liberty of the Press and those who conduct 1t,
among body of men where the idea was entertain.
ed of furnishing editor for publishing one OF their
own resolutions !!

Too cheap by half The following very modest
and patriotic offer was made in Ohio, at the late
election, by one Of the genuine disciples OF Ol0
Hickory:


II will support the cause of Gen. Jackson in th'
Legislature at their next session, 1t the people o
this county thinks me worthy, for sirty too cent
and half per dug. ;,
